Literature Review: Lipid droplets (LDs) are essential organelles found in virtually all eukaryotic cells, playing a crucial role in lipid metabolism and energy homeostasis. In plants, these organelles, also known as oil bodies or lipid bodies, have garnered significant attention due to their importance in seed oil storage and potential applications in biotechnology and bioenergy production. This literature review aims to synthesize current knowledge on plant lipid droplets, focusing on their structure, composition, biogenesis, and diverse functions across different plant tissues.The basic structure of lipid droplets consists of a hydrophobic core of neutral lipids, primarily triacylglycerols (TAGs), surrounded by a phospholipid monolayer embedded with various proteins. This unique architecture allows LDs to efficiently store and compartmentalize hydrophobic molecules within the aqueous cytoplasm of plant cells. The protein composition of the LD surface is complex and dynamic, with several well-characterized proteins and numerous newly discovered ones (Chapman et al., 2012).Oleosins, caleosins, and steroleosins are among the most abundant and well-studied LD-associated proteins in plants. Oleosins, in particular, play a crucial role in maintaining LD stability and controlling their size. These proteins have a conserved central hydrophobic domain that anchors them to the LD surface, with N- and C-terminal domains facing the cytosol (Huang, 2018). Recent proteomic studies have revealed a more diverse array of proteins associated with LDs, including enzymes involved in lipid metabolism, signaling proteins, and structural proteins (Pyc et al., 2017).The biogenesis of lipid droplets in plants is a complex process that involves the coordinated action of multiple cellular compartments and protein complexes. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) plays a central role in LD formation, with neutral lipids accumulating between the leaflets of the ER membrane before budding off to form nascent LDs (Thiam and Beller, 2017). Recent studies have identified key proteins involved in this process, such as SEIPIN, which forms oligomeric complexes at ER-LD contact sites and is crucial for proper LD formation (Cai et al., 2015).While lipid droplets are most abundant in oil-rich tissues like seeds, where they serve as energy reserves for germination, they are present in virtually all plant cells and perform diverse functions beyond storage. In vegetative tissues, LDs have been implicated in stress responses, hormone signaling, and membrane remodeling (Shimada et al., 2018). For instance, LDs in leaves have been shown to sequester toxic lipids and participate in jasmonate biosynthesis during plant defense responses (Shimada and Hara-Nishimura, 2015).The plasticity of lipid droplet metabolism in plants has been demonstrated through remarkable metabolic engineering efforts. Researchers have successfully increased TAG accumulation in vegetative tissues by manipulating key enzymes and transcription factors involved in lipid biosynthesis and storage (Vanhercke et al., 2014). These achievements not only provide insights into the regulation of LD formation but also open up new possibilities for bioenergy production and the engineering of high-value lipophilic compounds in plants.Evolutionary studies have revealed both conservation and divergence in the molecular machinery associated with lipid droplets across different organisms. While some components, such as the core TAG synthesis enzymes, are highly conserved, others, like oleosins, are plant-specific adaptations (Huang, 2018). Comparative genomic and proteomic analyses have provided valuable insights into the evolution of LD-associated proteins and their functions in different plant species (Huang, 2018).Despite significant advances in our understanding of plant lipid droplets, several important questions remain unanswered. The precise mechanisms governing LD size regulation, intracellular movement, and interactions with other organelles are still not fully understood. Additionally, the roles of newly discovered LD-associated proteins and their potential functions in non-storage contexts require further investigation (Pyc et al., 2017).In conclusion, lipid droplets are dynamic and multifunctional organelles that play crucial roles in plant cell biology beyond their classical function as lipid storage compartments. The growing body of knowledge on LD composition, biogenesis, and functions has not only enhanced our understanding of plant lipid metabolism but also opened up new avenues for biotechnological applications. Future research focusing on the molecular mechanisms of LD dynamics, their interactions with other cellular components, and their diverse functions in different plant tissues will undoubtedly provide valuable insights into plant biology and contribute to the development of novel strategies for crop improvement and bioenergy production.
